title: New Day Cafe - Saturday: Scenes Of Snow
text: Good morning, all you glorious Newdists. You know how much I yearn for snow. We‚Äôre doing snow today! I hope you all are in good health (no COVID, no flu, no bone aches etc.) and thriving in this winter weather. Newdists, recently, I‚Äôve limited my time on X, and have been the better for it. How are you all handling the world wide stuff? First, da critters ‚Äî Your Cafe's wild kitteh ‚Äî A bobcat photographed with my DSLR camera trap in the Diablo Range! pic.twitter.com/WrD1j5T3k1‚Äî Vishal Subramanyan (@vishalfoto) January 5, 2024 A bobcat photographed with my DSLR camera trap in the Diablo Range! pic.twitter.com/WrD1j5T3k1 Your Cafe‚Äôs Owls ‚Äî Owl ears are large compared to other bird species, and Long-eared Owls have some of the largest ears of any owl species. When looking at the ears, we are primarily checking for parasites, bruising, or wounds. Check out how big the ears of a Long-eared owl are! pic.twitter.com/1RlRMjuDKJ‚Äî World Bird Sanctuary (@WBSSTL) January 10, 2024 Owl ears are large compared to other bird species, and Long-eared Owls have some of the largest ears of any owl species. When looking at the ears, we are primarily checking for parasites, bruising, or wounds. Check out how big the ears of a Long-eared owl are! pic.twitter.com/1RlRMjuDKJ . A Short-eared owl hunting on the Kings Links Aberdeen. They vary quite a bit in their plumage. This one has quite a pale face and bronzed wings and tail #NatureGoneWild #TwitterNatureCommunity #TwitterNaturePhotography #BirdsSeenin2024 #naturelovers #NatureLover #nature pic.twitter.com/qGA2yczd6t‚Äî Ron Macdonald (@ronpon_ron) January 4, 2024 A Short-eared owl hunting on the Kings Links Aberdeen. They vary quite a bit in their plumage. This one has quite a pale face and bronzed wings and tail #NatureGoneWild #TwitterNatureCommunity #TwitterNaturePhotography #BirdsSeenin2024 #naturelovers #NatureLover #nature pic.twitter.com/qGA2yczd6t Snowy owls nest on the tundra ground, a hideaway from predators among grass. pic.twitter.com/PXPNVrRmU0‚Äî explore.org (@exploreorg) January 11, 2024 Snowy owls nest on the tundra ground, a hideaway from predators among grass. pic.twitter.com/PXPNVrRmU0 The elusive snowy owl can live in temperatures colder than -60 degrees Farenheit. pic.twitter.com/vEGDoB0IM1‚Äî explore.org (@exploreorg) January 6, 2024 The elusive snowy owl can live in temperatures colder than -60 degrees Farenheit. pic.twitter.com/vEGDoB0IM1 Dearest Newdists, please grab a cuppa, a plate of food, ogle some photos, and join us in the thread with a big blankie to stay warm. Brrr! (sigh) Forecast cold, for Jan 13-17 pic.twitter.com/WieSpgLlou‚Äî G R 406 (@406_gr) January 12, 2024 Forecast cold, for Jan 13-17 pic.twitter.com/WieSpgLlou This is the mountain I learned to ski on. It wasn‚Äôt called a ‚Äúresort‚Äù then. It was simply Solitude Mountain. I've resented that ‚Äúresort‚Äù ever since they added it. A day to play in the sun before the next storm comes! GPS will give you shortest route, but it may not be a safe route; these devices do not take into consideration roads closed during the winter. #KnowBeforeYouGo pic.twitter.com/oIVtSzDLTm‚Äî Forest Service NW (@ForestServiceNW) January 13, 2024 Relying on GPS directions is not a good idea in winter.
